each function call registers itself at the backend manager
or rather, it reassigns all registered functions to point to the backend counterparts
the use_backend function will not be able to alter that reference

an if + a hash will be around ~120ns on a fast machine. That's not too bad.
@scolbert: for the single-call change use-case, why not just rely on explicit import
The main way of switching a backend would be a use_backend("backend") call
that call reassigns the function in the module to point to the backend function, thus no overhead
also, I'm still reading the code on github
it's trading more end-user work for developer work.
my argument is the case where you want to switch between backends in a module for some reason, you should have to pay a high switching cost.
Just saying there's a usecase where you don't want module level use_backend(...) calls all over the place
Yes, use_backend() needs to be explicit in its documentation that previous imports are not handled.

so you would still get the docs. In fact, that would be a better doc since it would immediately tell you which backends implement the func

something like:
